column18: Aaron, who used no last name, became an antislavery lecturer and memoir author who was critical of northern hypocrisy

column10: Fled enslavement and made his way to Florida
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Abraham escaped from slavery, joined the Seminole, acted as an interpreter following the Indian Removal Act of 1830 and fought alongside the Seminole after treaty negotiations broke down

column10: Enslaved her entire life.
column13: Parents were enslaved and came from Barbados.
column15: Illiterate.
column16: Christian. A member of Christ Church in Philadelphia.
column18: Interacted with many local notables while working at a ferry. A centenarian and oral historian.

column10: No evidence that he was freed
column13: Unknown. He was listed as mixed race
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Billy was condemned to death on charges of treason for  allegedly planning to make war on Virginia. Thomas Jefferson initiated a temporary reprieve, which the state legislature extended

column10: Escaped from the slave ship on which he was being transported
column13: Unknown
column14: Escaped from the slave ship on which he was being transported
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Made a career as a pirate, joined the famed Blackbeard aboard The Queen Anne's Revenge, and was hanged for his illegal activities

column10: Freeborn
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Musician

column10: Unclear if she was ever freed. Born in Barbados; presumably enslaved from birth. Disappeared from historical record after Salem Witch Trials.
column13: Unknown.
column15: No evidence of schooling. She claimed her mistress made her write her name
column16: Claimed to be a witch when accused in Salem, and handed over voodoo dolls.
column18: Subverted institution of slavery and prejudices by accusing her owner of making her into a witch.

column10: In 1842 her father Jacob Bryan (plantation owner) manumitted Celia's mother and several children, possibly including Celia.
column13: Father was Jacob Bryan, a white planter. Mother, Susan, was enslaved and was Bryan's common-law wife.
column15: No evidence of literacy.
column18: Executed after being charged with killing Jacob Bryan, who was her father and possibly the father of her four children.

column10: Never freed.
column13: Unknown.
column14: Killed her owner in self defense. Escaped from jail while on death row but was recaptured.
column15: No evidence of literacy.
column18: Executed by hanging in 1855 for killing her master while resisting his attempt to rape her.

column10: Unknown
column11: Seminole. Seized by slave hunters
column13: possibly the daughter of a former slave and a prominent Creek or Seminole man
column15: No evidence of literacy

column10: No evidence that he was ever freed.
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Also known as Cuffee, he organized an insurrection in Manhattan with over twenty enslaved Africans and two enslaved Native Americans

column10: Apparently freed by Emancipation
column13: Parents were enslaved
column15: Literate
column18: A technically skilled potter who inscribed poetry and dates into his work. He was possibly the same individual known in oral tradition as one-legged Dave of Edgefield

column10: Apparently earned enough money through his work as a doctor to purchase his own freedom. By 1853 he was listed in the Nashville business directory as “Jack, Root Doctor"
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment.  A doctor who used roots and herbs to heal. After the 1831 Tennessee General Assembly banned enslaved persons from practicing medicine, over 120 white citizens petitioned for Doctor Jack to have an exemption.

column10: Given her freedom at age 30 by a Presbyterian minister.
column13: Unknown. Her father was literate.
column15: Unclear.
column17: Dictated a memoir when 100 years old: A Colored Minister of the Gospel, Born in Slavery. https://docsouth.unc.edu/neh/eliza2/eliza2.html
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Autobiography was published posthumously by Quakers.

column8: Status changed during the Civil War
column10: After recovering from a vicious whipping, he escaped from slavery in March 1863 by traveling  east toward the Mississippi River and Union lines
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Gordon became widely known for a photograph (taken at the time of his enlistment in the Union military) that showed scars on his back

column10: Never freed.
column13: Unknown
column15: Jemmy was possibly the same person as Cato, a literate leader in the Stono uprising
column16: Likely practiced a combination of Roman Catholicism and older African faiths
column18: Born in central Africa, Jemmy led the 1739 Stono slave rebellion, which was the deadliest revolt in colonial North America

column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Joe survived the battle of the Alamo and left an account of the fighting

column10: No evidence that he was ever freed
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Known for his attempt to patent his invention, the “Stuart Double Plough and Double Scraper" for harvesting cotton

column10: Never freed.
column13: Unknown names. His parents were brought from Africa to North America while Pomp was a baby
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: After three unsuccessful attempts to escape enslavement, each of which was followed by cruel punishment, Pomp killed his master and was sentenced to the gallows.

column10: Unknown
column11: Unknown Status, Free after 1865
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Possibly named Morris Slater or Bill McCoy, he "freeloaded" aboard trains and defended himself with a rifle. This made him both a "wanted" suspect and a folk hero.

column10: Never freed
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Enslaved in the Caribbean and then in Trenton, NJ. Romain committed suicide so as to avoid being returned to Caribbean slavery.

column10: Possibly ran away to British lines during the American Revolution
column11: Unknown status. Possible runaway
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Possibly a runaway and possibly the slave of a Loyalist, Sampson worked as a coastal pilot for the British during the American Revolution

column10: William Clark, who was the owner of York under the laws of the time, reported in 1832 that he had freed York
column13: His father was an enslaved African American also named York; his mother was likely enslaved by the same family
column15: Likely illiterate.
column18: York joined the Lewis and Clark expedition, becoming the first African American to cross North America from coast-to-coast north of Mexico.

column10: Freeborn
column13: Father was George W. Jeffrey. Mother was Mary Ann (Campbell), whose original status is unknown
column18: Freeborn barber, orator, and activist

column10: Unknown. Possibly freed by the Civil War or 13th Amendment.
column13: Son of Aaron and Louisa, both enslaved
column15: Illiterate
column18: Aarons survived slavery and gave an oral interview in 1937 in the context of the Federal Writers' Project, which had been established by FDR

column10: Freeborn
column13: His parents were Wilson Ruffin Abbott, a businessman and properties investor, and Mary Ellen Toyer. They had arrived in Toronto in 1835.
column15: Literate. Attended Buxton Mission School, was one of three Black students at  Toronto Academy, attended the preparatory department of Oberlin College, and studeid at Toronto School of Medicine.
column16: Associate editor of a newspaper run by the British Methodist Episcopal Church. He also surved as a warden for the St. James Anglican Church
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A licensed physician who served in the Civil War as an assistant surgeon and captain. Abbott was an intellectual, a writer, and a proponent of school desegregation and classical education

column10: Freeborn
column13: The son of Israel B. Abbott and Gracie Maria Green
column14: Escaped after being forced to work in support of the Confederate army
column15: Attended school from age 4 to 10.
column16: Unknown. One of his fathers-in-law was a Methodist Episcopal Zion Church minister
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A reformer, debater and orator who held various appointed public offices in 1872 was elected as a Republican to the NC House of Representatives. Also co-founded a Laborers Union

column10: Wrote a letter in Arabic and sent it to Morocco to request his freedom. Two years later a letter was sent in response to the U.S. State Department requesting Abd al-Rahman's freedom. Residents of Natchez, Mississippi raised funds to buy his wife's freedom and the two were transported to Liberia.
column13: Born into the Bari family of the Fulbe people
column14: Ran away for several weeks but returned.
column15: Literate. Prior to enslavement he learned to read and write Arabic in Fula-Muslim schools.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A West African military leader who was captured into slavery, Abd al-Rahman became a well-known antislavery activist after securing his own freedom and raising funds to free his children.

column10: As a young man he left the place norhern Maryland where he had been born. Unclear if he was ever enslaved.
column11: Unknown  Status at Birth,  free before 1866
column13: Born to Andrew Abel and Delila Williams
column15: Unknown. He was an ordained priest
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An early African American priest in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints who migrated to Utah and who encountered significant prejudice within the religion

column10: Not freed until 19 June 1865, when federal troops arrived in Texas to announce and implement the Emancipation Proclamation
column13: His parents, Sarah and Pete, were the property of a family named Abner
column15: Likely literate. One of the eight incorporators of Bishop College
column16: A founding member of Bethesda Baptist Church
column18: Formerly enslaved in Alabama and Texas, Abner served a term in the Texas state legislature in 1874 and was a delegate to the state constitutional convention the following year

column10: Freeborn?
column11: Unclear if he was ever enslaved
column13: The younger son of Reverend Henry, a school administrator, and Margaret Priscilla (Corbin) Adams.
column15: Literate. Graduated from preparatory school and college at Oberlin College
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Adams was a journalist who was involved in Republican politics, spoke four languages,  and served as three-term president of the National Afro-American Press Association among other club activities.

column10: May have hired out his time to purchase his freedom. Joined the Union army during the Civil War
column13: Parents are unknown.
column15: Unclear. Ran for local office in 1872.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A successful carpenter and founder of a black militia in Hamburg, South Carolina, members of which were massacred by armed men led by a former Confederate general.

column10: May have been born into slavery and escaped from bondage before the Civil War
column13: Unknown
column15: No formal education.
column18: A cowboy in Texas who was effectively the friend effectively the business partner of a white rancher

column10: Freeborn
column13: His  parents were free (names unknown)
column15: Literate. Studied the Bible and was proficient in English and Latin
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A Baptist preacher who in 1842 became the first preacher of the First African Baptist Church when it split from the First Baptist Church

column10: Emancipated in 1865, although he had become economically self-sufficient before then
column13: Unknown
column15: Literate. Learned to read and write while serving in the U.S. army
column16: Described as someone who “feared God but not man”
column18: A veteran of the U.S. military and faith healer who promoted emigration to Liberia and also testified before the U.S. senate on the so-called Exodus to Kansas

column10: Freeborn
column13: The son of Henry Adams, a minister and educator, and Margaret Corbin
column15: Literate. Attended private schools in Wisconsin and Ohio and graduated from Oberlin College
column16: Unclear. A newspaper he owned was subsumed by the American Baptist
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A newspaper editor, two-time secretary in Republican state conventions in Arkansas, educator, and co-founder of the National Afro-American League

column10: Adams and his family escaped from their plantation on 27 June 1862 and were provided by a Union officer with a pass to Philadelphia
column13: One of twenty-five children born to his mother, an enslaved woman (name unknown). His father was also enslaved
column15: Literate. Determinedly pursued an education
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Formerly enslaved man who prized education and wrote an autobiography

column10: May have been enslaved in Mississippi and brought to Texas in 1850. It is unclear if he was freed before the 13th amendment.
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: A highly skilled cowboy in New Mexico who was a respected range boss but in his later years was dogged by increasingly virulent racism

column10: He was reportedly a slave owned by Captain John Paul Jones, but had gained his freedompriortothe American Revolution
column11: Unknown  Status at Birth, free before 1866
column13: Unknown
column15: Unknown. Participated in a petition
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Served in the Navy during the American Revolution aboard the Ranger and was one of several crewmembers to petition the American commissioners in France for better treatment of a ship officer

column10: Born ca. 1822 to enslaved parents. Slavery was abolished in New York State in 1827, so Africanus was free at this time (if not earleir)
column11: Unknown Status at Birth, free before 1866
column13: His parents, whose names are unknown, were enslaved.
column15: Literate. A writer and a teacher.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A writer and teacher who urged civil disobedience against the Fugitive Slave Act and who often conveyed his ideas in poetic form.

column10: Emancipated in 1834 after almost 3 decades of enslavement in Jamaica when Richard Madden, a traveler, learned of al-Saddiq's literacy, encouraged him to translate his autobiography, and negotiated his sale and emancipation
column13: Son of Kara Muso, who was in a long line of literate and learned Muslim leaders
column15: Literate in Arabic
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Author of an autobiographical account, al-Saddiq was trained in Jenné by several ulama (scholars), enslaved for decades in Jamaica, and ultimately repatriated

column10: Unknown. Possibly freed by the Civil War or 13th Amendment.
column13: the daughter of unnamed slaves.
column15: literate. Enrolled at Atlanta University aged 17 in 1870. Published a book (posthumously). The House of Bondage; or, Charlotte Brooks and Other Slaves. (1890)
column16: Christian. Husband was Methodist Episcopal minister

column10: Apparently emancipated after the Civil War
column13: Both parents were enslaved; their names are unknown.
column14: No evidence of runaway. A member of Lincoln's Legal Loyal League that passed information to Union forces during the Civil War.
column15: Literate. Learned to read and write as a child even though it was illegal in Mississippi. Began attending school in 1865 and trained as a teacher.
column18: A member of the Mississippi legislature from 1873 to 1879 who helped pass civil rights legislation, he was threatened by the Ku Klux Klan and ultimately left or was forced from public life, settling in Colorado

column10: Apparently never enslaved
column13: His parents were Daniel Aldridge, a minister, and Lurona (maiden name unknown)
column15: Literate. Attended African Free School in New York City.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An actor who emigrated to England and made his debut in 1825 under the name Mr. Keene and who toured widely throughout Europe.

column10: Passed information to Union soldiers and then fled from enslavement. Though captured, he again escaped and traveled to St. Louis. Slave catchers were sent to retrieve him but Archer was able to secure freedom through connections with the Union forces.
column13: His parents, Aleck and Chloe, were enslaved
column15: Unknown. His father was literate.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Described by William Greenleaf Eliot's The Story of Archer Alexander. From Slavery to Freedom, March 30, 1863 and portrayed in the Freedmen's Memorial to Abraham Lincoln, Archer was a fugitive slave who helped members of his family escape slavery

column10: Unclear when he was emancipated. Before the civil war he had traveled in France with his father and studied in New Jersey
column13: Son of Sosthene Allain, a wealthy white planter, and an enslaved woman
column15: Literate. Studied with private tutors in New Orleans and at a private college in New Jersey. Fluent in French.
column18: One of the wealthiest people of color in Louisiana during reconstruction, Allain helped found Southern University and served terms in the state house and Senate between 1872 and 1890, after which his finances went into decline

column10: Gained his freedom in 1796
column13: His mother was likely enslaved; his father was a freeman and mariner
column15: Literate.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A former slave and mariner, Allen settled in Hawai'i where he was a steward to King Kamehameha I, the recipient of a land grant, and a businessman who operated a tavern and medical facility

column10: Unknown
column11: Unknown Status at Birth, free before 1791, when she helped her husband buy property in Philadelphia
column13: Unknown
column15: Unknown
column16: Methodist. Helped  husband inaugurate the Bethel African Methodist Church
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Her entry is combined with that of Sarah Allen

column10: Unknown. Possibly freeborn.
column11: Unknown Status at Birth, free before 1866
column13: Unknown
column15: Literate. Became a member of the Maine bar in 1844
column18: The first African American in the U.S. who was licensed to practice law. He apparently also became the first appointed African American judicial official in 1847 when he became a justice of the peace in MA

column10: He and his brother purchased their freedom in 1780 after being permitted to work
column13: His parents were enslaved
column15: Educational background is unclear, but he published articles in Freedom's Journal and supported education
column16: Methodist. Founder of the African Methodist Episcopal church
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Founded the first independent black church in North America, joined with other black churches to establish the African Methodist Episcopal (AME) Church, and published a hymnbook. Also an abolitionist leader who opposed the colonization movement

column10: Emancipated after the Civil War
column13: His parents are unknown
column15: Literate by 1870, though no formal education
column18: A carpenter, storekeeper, quartermaster in a black militia, masonic lodge leader and political leader who was a delegate of National Colored Men's Convention and of the Republican National Convention

column10: Unknown
column13: Born as Sarah Bass, possibly to enslaved parents of the same surname
column15: Likely literate. Signed property deeds and  purchased a copy of a friend's autobiography.
column16: Methodist. Husband was a bishop and founder of the African Methodist Episcopal (AME) Church
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Likely enslaved until the 1780s or 1790s, by which time she moved to Pennsylvania. Her entry is combined with that of Flora Allen.

column10: Freeborn
column13: His mother was a free woman of mixed heritage; his father was white.
column15: Literate. Studied at the Oneida Institute in Whitesboro, New York. He later studied law
column16: Unknown. He taught at New York Central College, which had been founded by the American Baptist Free Mission Society
column18: A professor and abolitionist who authored an autobiographical account, The American Prejudice against Color: An Authentic Narrative, Showing How Easily the Nation Got into an Uproar

column10: When the Confederate general Braxton Bragg's advance reached Louisville, Allensworth was invited to become a member of the hospital corps of the Forty-fourth Illinois and became a freeman.
column13: The youngest of six children born to Levi Allensworth and Phyllis, who were enslaved
column14: Fled at age 13 but was soon recaptured.
column15: Played school with a white boy, taught in a Quaker-led afternoon slave school, and studied secretly with a white boy. After the Civil War he attended Ely Normal School for freemen and the Theological Institute at Nashville
column18: Free before 13th Amendment.  After serving in the military during the Civil War, he was a teacher, Baptist preacher, Republican political figure,  chaplain, lieutenant colonel, and the co-founder of an all-black community in California called Allensworth

column10: Unknown
column13: Mother was Mary Dickinson (also enslaved), father was a white man in the Leavell family
column15: Literate. Attended Nashville Normal and Theological Institute sometime between 1868 and 1875. Later taught Sunday school and worked as a telegrapher.
column16: Probably Baptist. Husband was a Baptist minister.
column18: Her father wanted to send her north on the Underground Railroad, but her mother disagreed.

column10: Likely a free black at the time of his enlistment in the Union navy
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. One of the approximately 18,000 African Americans to serve in the Union navy during the Civil War, Anderson earned the Medal of Honor for his service.

column10: Freeborn
column13: His parents' names were unrecorded in the census. It is possible that they were Samuel and Mary Anderso.
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Enlisted in a white regiment during the Civil War and in 1914 was very belatedly awarded the Medal of Honor for his service

column10: Freeborn
column13: Eldest daughter of the abolitionist movement leaders William Still and Letitia George Still
column15: Literate. Studied at Oberlin College
column16: Christian. Married to a Presbyterian minister
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An early African American woman doctor who also served as an active club member and assistant school principal

column10: Ran away in 1853 and fatally stabbed a planter, Seneca Digges, who tried to arrest him. The Underground Railroad helped him escape to Canada.
column13: Parents are unknown.
column15: Educated in England
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Risked extradition from Canada to Missouri for killing a white man while escaping from slavery, but avoided that fate and traveled to England, where he was an antislavery lecturer. Moved to Liberia in 1862

column10: Freeborn
column13: One of fourteen children of Timothy Anderson and Mary Croog
column15: Literate. Studied at Oberlin College in Ohio, graduating in 1874. The first African American to live on campus while studying at Princeton Theological Seminary, where he finished his studies in 1877. He then took courses at Yale Divinity School.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Founded a Presbyterian church, opened the Berean Building and Loan Association, and in 1899 started the Berean Manual Training and Industrial School

column10: Freeborn
column13: His parents were free. His father was a man named Vincent Anderson, and his mother may have been Irish or Scottish.
column15: Literate. Possibly attended Oberlin College.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. One of five black men to join John Brown's raid at Harper's Ferry. Anderson managed to escape and wrote  A Voice from Harper's Ferry (1861).

column10: Apparently freeborn
column13: Unknown
column15: Literate
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Anderson had worked as a tailor in California and then founded or contributed to several African American newspapers

column8: Status changed during the Civil War
column10: Received permission from his owner, a Kentucky planter, to enlist in the Union Army. Anderson joined the 125th Colored Infantry, Company G, on 22 April 1865
column13: Anderson's mother was enslaved on a plantation. His father, William Anderson, was enslaved on a nearby plantation.
column15: Unknown. His wife helped him write a memoir.
column18: Survived slavery and served in the military for two years. By 1920 Anderson owned a remarkable 2,080 acres in Nebraska, which was more than any other black man at the time

column10: Freeborn
column13: The son of Richard and Mary Lott Anderson, who were from Kentucky and Indiana, respectively
column15: Literate. Graduated from Detroit High School in 1875
column16: Unstated. Some of his work was published in the A.M.E. Church Review
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Co-founded The Detroit Plaindealer, which was one of the leading African American newspapers, and co-authored works of fiction. Also active in associations such as the Afro-American League

column8: Status changed during the Civil War
column10: During the Civil War he and his mother fled to Galveston, Texas
column13: His mother was enslaved. Parents' names are unknown
column15: Literate. Studied for three years at Wilberforce University in Ohio, earned a theology certificate from Howard University in 1886,  and graduated from the Homeopathic Medical College of Cleveland
column18: Co-authored Under Fire with the Tenth Cavalry (1899) while a chaplain with an all-black unit

column10: Released from enslavement on the condition that he serve in the Continental army
column13: Unknown
column15: Illiterate
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Gained his freedom by serving in the army and then purchased his wife's freedom

column10: Freeborn
column13: His parents' names are unknown. His father served in the War of 1812; his mother was from the West Indies and was the daughter of an African chief
column15: Literate. Attended private schools in New Orleans and became fluent in English and French. Earned a law degree from Straight University (later Dillard) in New Orleans
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Served in the Civil War, was a delegate at the Louisiana Constitutional Convention of 1867-1868 and state senator from 1868 to 1872, and is one of three African Americans to have been Lieutenant Governors of Louisiana

column10: Freeborn
column13: His parents' names are unknown. His father served in the War of 1812; his mother was from the West Indies and was the daughter of an African chief. Felix was the younger brother of  Caesar C. Antoine.
column15: Not stated. He was among the gens de couleur libre, who were the most educated property-owners in Louisiana
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Enlisted in Company B, Seventh Louisiana Infantry, on 3 July 1863, but resigned when General Nathaniel Banks tried to remove officers who were not white. Served in the Louisiana House of Representatives from 1868 to 1872. After the end of Reconstruction he worked in a customs house and served in the Grand Army of the Republic

column10: Freeborn
column13: The son of Samuel G. Arnett and Mary Louisa (maiden name unknown). Benjamin was described as being of “mixed Irish, Indian, Scots, and African ancestry”
column15: Literate. Educated in a one_room schoolhouse in Bridgeport, Pennsylvania
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A teacher and then an AME preacher and elder who became general secretary in 1880 among other roles and a bishop in 1888. Also the chaplain to the Ohio legislature in 1879 and in 1886 was elected to the legislature representing the predominately white Greene County

column10: Status at birth is unstated. In 1826 his parents and he migrated from Mississippi to Texas and Hendrick Arnold lived as a free black from then on.
column11: Unknown Status at Birth, free before 1866
column13: The son of Daniel and Rachel Arnold. His father was likely white; his mother was African American.
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An early free black in Texas who served as a guide during some of the key engagements leading up to Texas' Independence and received a land grant for his service

column10: Unknown. Possibly freed by the Civil War or 13th Amendment.
column13: His father was Jeremiah Arter, a miller by trade, and his mother was Hannah Frances Stephenson. Both parents were enslaved
column15: Literate. Attended Storer College in Harpers Ferry and in 1879 started at Pennsylvania State College. Earned a Bachelor in Philosophy from Hillsdale College in Michigan in 1885 and in 1894 earned a Bachelor of Divinity from Chicago Theological Seminary
column18: A Baptist preacher and temperance activist who was president of the West Virginia Industrial School Seminary and College in Hill Top

column10: Freeborn
column13: Unknown. He was of one quarter African and three quarters European ancestry
column15: Received a basic British-style education in Nassau in the Bahamas
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. In 1870 he migrated from the Bahamas to Florida, becoming an educator, a temperance reformer active in the Good Templars, and holding multiple appointed positions

column10: Freeborn
column13: Parents were William P. Wallingford, an immigrant farmer from England, and Viola, his former slave
column15: Literate. Attended University of Kansas
column16: Played music for several African Methodist Episcopal (AME) churches, and was a member of the Baha'i faith for twenty_five years
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Possibly the first black woman in America to receive a PhD, Asberry was a pianist who lived primarily in Kansas and Washington State

column10: Apparently freeborn
column13: His parents were Ruel and Jereusha Asher. His father was a shoemaker and his moher was Native American
column15: Attended school until age 12 in North Branford, where the other pupils were white.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Protested discriminatory seating in the predominately white Baptist church he initially attended, then founded his own church and raised money by touring England and publishing Incidents in the Life of the Rev. J. Asher (1850). One of 14 Black chaplains in the Union army.

column10: Freeborn
column13: The second son of Nelson Askin and Sarah Lloyd, who were living in Massachusetts at the time of his birth.
column15: He and his siblings left school early to pursue work.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. The first African American to integrate baseball

column10: Ran away in 1750, when he was about twenty-seven
column13: Likely of mixed African, Native American and white ancestry
column15: No evidence of literacy
column16: Unknown. Likely a descendent of a group of Natick Indians converted to Christianity
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A former slave and mariner who was the first person killed in the Boston Massacre

column10: Freeborn
column13: The oldest child of a Scottish father (whose first name is thought to be William), and Mary McFarland Jennings, a school teacher from VA.
column15: Literate. Graduated from Philadelphia Institute for Colored Youth (later Cheney State Teacher's College)
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An early school principal who was also trained in nursing

column10: Likely freed when all enslaved persons in the British Empire were formally emancipated in 1833.
column13: His mother was likely a slave in the household of Lydia A. Sandiford in Barbados
column15: Literate. Studied at an Episcopalian divinity school in west Philadelphia
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Originally from Barbados, Atwell was the first man of African descent to be ordained an Episcopal priest in a southern U.S. diocese

column10: Freeborn
column13: His parents' names and occupations are unknown.
column15: Literate. He was educated by a Bishop Payne even though Virginia law at the time prohibited the education of African Americans. He was denied admittance to the University of Pennsylvania but a professor let Augusta study in his office. Earned a Bachelor of Medicine in 1856 from Trinity Medical College in Toronto
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. The first African American to lead a hospital, the first African American to be brevetted lieutenant colonel in the U.S. Volunteer Corps, and the first African American faculty member at a U.S. medical school. Helped found the first African American medical society in the U.S.

column10: Unknown
column11: Unknown Status at Birth. Born Virginia, 1865
column13: Daughter of Richard and Sylvia Crews (who had been enslaved)
column15: Literate; a public school teacher.
column16: Christian. A member of the Bethel African Methodist Episcopal church and later of the North Oakland Baptist Church.
column18: Public school teacher Described in Negro Trailblazers, a compilation published by Delilah Beasley in 1919. https://babel.hathitrust.org/cgi/pt?id=uc1.32106000667540;view=1up;seq=9

column10: Saved money while working on Sundays. It is unclear whether he purchased his freedom from his father (who was legally his owner) or if he was freed
column13: His father, J. D. Badger, was a white dentist and Roderick's owner. His mother (name unknown) was enslaved
column15: Few details of his formal education are known. He learned dentistry from his father
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A dentist in Atlanta before and after the Civil War (during the war he was an aide to a Confederate army colonel) who attained financial success in spite of prejudice. Also the first black trustee of Clark College.

column10: Most likely a freeman
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy, although the details of his schooling and photography training are unknown
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A skilled photographer and early daguerrean who trained  James Presley Ball, a famous abolitionist, how to make daguerrotypes

column10: Freed after six years serving in the Continental Army. His emancipation in 1783 may have been based on a preexisting contract
column13: Unknown.
column15: No evidence of literacy.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Discharged from the Continental Army in a letter signed by General George Washington, Brister became a freedman after his six years of military service

column10: Likely born enslaved. Few details of his early life (and emancipation, if applicable) are known
column13: Unknown.
column15: Probably literate.
column18: Appointed by President William McKinley to be a postmaster of a predominately white community in South Carolina, Baker, and one of his children, was brutally lynched in an attack that gained national attention

column10: Freeborn
column13: One of seven children of William and Harriet Lego Cole
column15: Unknown. She served as a pastor, wrote hymns, and helped at Sunday school.
column16: Evangelical. An African Methodist Episcopal (AME) minister who spoke at Methodist Episcopal, Primitive Methodist, United Brethren, Baptist, Methodist Protestant, and AME Zion churches
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A mother of twelve who saw seven children die, Baker was an early evangelical preacher

column10: Little is known about his early life.
column11: Unknown  Status at Birth. Born Mississippi, 1859
column13: Unknown
column15: Literate. Attended public schools and the Columbus Union Academy. Became the third African American to begin studying at the naval academy in Anapolis, but left in 1876 after severe hazing. Enrolled at Ben-Hyde Benton School of Technology, then attended Howard University's law school and graduated in 1881. Completed postgraduate law studies there in 1883
column18: Baker was the third African American to enroll at the naval academy, a lawyer, a supporter of the Howard University neighborhood, the first African American Patent Examiner, and the author of The Colored Inventor: A Record of Fifty Years

column10: Unknown. Possibly freed by the Civil War or 13th Amendment.
column13: His parents were enslaved. His father, Thomas Chadwick Baker, was a Civil War veteran. His mother was Edith (Nottingham) Baker
column15: Literate. Learned to read from his mother. Later studied at Hampton Institute in Virginia, Mount Hermon School in Massachusetts,  Boston University (B.A. in 1893), Yale Divinity School (Bachelor in Divinity, and in 1903 PhD in Philosophy)
column18: The first African American to earn a PhD in philosophy, Baker went on to write important works on black values, aesthetics, and ideals, arguing for “Not Pity but Respect" for black people.

column10: Freeborn
column13: The daughter of Peter L. Baldwin, who was Haitian, and Mary E. (Blake) Baldwin
column15: Literate. Graduated in 1881 from Cambridge Teachers' Training School and continued her studies in subsequent years
column16: Involved in the Unitarian Universalist Church
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An early school master and an active club member in Cambridge and Boston, MA

column10: Escaped from slavery in 1807 after being severely beaten. Was caught and imprisoned in Virginia but escaped from jail and walked from Georgia to Maryland. Recaptured in 1830 but escaped again, only to find that his free wife and children had been illegally captured into slavery during his absence
column13: His parents were enslaved; their names are unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Ball's story was discussed in a ghostwritten memoir, Fifty Years in Chains (1859)

column10: Freeborn
column13: The second child born to William Ball and Susan Ball, who were free blacks

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An abolitionist and daguerreotypist who in 1855 produced a 2,400 square yard panorama depicting the slave trade

column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: A waiter, servant, or bugler who saved a relative of George Washington during the Revolutionary War

column10: It was widely assumed that he was born enslaved in Kentucky, but he arrived in California as a free man before the start of the Civil War.
column11: Unknown  Status at Birth, free before 1866
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An early settler in Los Angeles County, California, who was a blacksmith, teamster, firewood salesman, and landowner

column10: Freeborn
column13: His parents, Thomas and Hannah Baltimore, were free blacks
column15: Attended various Sunday schools and the school of Enoch Ambush, but was unable to write his name upon finishing his studies. He later studied at the  Franklin Institute
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Baltimore was an inventor, machinist, and engineer who improved the steam boiler and was apprenticed at the Washington navy yards until driven away by harassment. He later opened a repair shop, was chief engineer/mechanic for Freedman's Hospital in D.C. and taught metalworking. Invented the pyrometer.

column10: Purchased her own freedom
column13: Her father was white (name unknown); her mother, Lydia, was enslaved
column15: Unknown
column16: Christian. A Methodist and then a member of the African Methodist Episcopal (AME) Church.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Purchased her mother's freedom

column10: Freeborn
column13: The son of Robert, a freed slave who had been born in Africa, and Mary Banneky, a daughter of a freed slave named Bannka and a freed English indentured servant named Molly Welsh
column15: Taught to read and write by his white grandmother. Briefly attended a Quaker one-room schoolhouse.
column16: Deeply religious. No particular religious affiliation
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A farmer who independently constructed a striking clock from wood before developing a passion for astronomy. He published an astronomy almanac, helped with the urban planning for Washington, D.C., and tried to convince Thomas Jefferson to become an abolitionist

column10: Freeborn
column13: His mother, Hannah Alexander, was from New Brunswick. His father was Edward Bannister, from Barbados

column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Enlisted in 1863 in the Twenty-fourth Regiment, United States Colored Infantry, a unit that saw such heavy casualties that it was combined with other companies

column15: Literate. Attended Koranic school as a child and later learned how to read and write in English. Studied for about three years at New York Central College
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Born in a Muslim merchant family in West Africa, he escaped from slavery in Brazil and later became an antislavery lecturer and author of an autobiography with an important account of the Middle Passage

column10: The details of his early life are unknown. By the mid-1820s he was a prominent member of Boston's African American communtiy
column13: Unknown
column15: The details of his education are unknown. Some of the organizations he helped found carried on correspondences.
column16: A member of African Baptist Church
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A political organizer who was a founder of the Massachusetts General Colored Association (MGCA) and of the Boston Colored Temperance Society, a defender of William Lloyd Garrison, and one of three African Americans to attend the founding meeting of the American Anti-Slavery Society (AASS)

column10: Emancipated by the Civil War
column13: His parents were Augustine Celestine, a slave, and Jean Barès, a white French-born carpenter
column15: Apparently literate. Published music.

column8: Status Uncertain: Possibly freed by service in the Union Army

column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy

column10: Freeborn
column13: Daughter of Julia Porter. Parents may have been enslaved; some sources suggest instead that her father was white

column8: Status Uncertain: Possibly freed by service in the Union Army

column13: Unknown
column15: Literate. Most likely self-educated.

column10: Unknown. Possibly freed by the Civil War or 13th Amendment.

column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: A famous horse trainer who organized the American Royal horse show, designed a bit that was more comfortable for horse's mouths, and won many horse races

column13: The son of Tobias Bassett, a mulatto, and Susan Bassett of the Shagticoke branch of the Pequot

column10: Freeborn
column13: Father was likely a Union soldier who died in the Civil War; mother was Mary Batson

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A renowned singer who went on three world tours

column13: Unknown
column15: Apparently literate. Credited with writing a pro-colonization tract

column10: Escaped from slavery in 1855
column13: Unknown
column15: Literate. Learned bookkeeping skills while enslaved

column8: Status changed during the Civil War
column10: Liberated by Union Forces
column13: Born to Milton Beard and Creasey Tatum, both former slaves on the Beard family plantation
column15: Illiterate
column16: Unknown. He built a wooden church.

column10: Unknown.

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Nun, and founder of the Third Order of Saint Francis

column13: Unknown
column15: Apprenticed in cabinetry and tutored by a retired actor

column15: Literate. Attended Cincinnati High School for Colored People at night

column18: Her father led 11 other people in escaping from slavery. Mary reunited with her parents after Civil War.

column18: Free before 13th Amendment.

column18: Free before 13th Amendment.

column18: Free before 13th Amendment.

Grimes, raised $1,200 from Bostonians to buy Burns' freedom, but Burns' master then raised the price. A posse of 2,000 armed men brought him back into slavery (at the cost of about $40,000). After suffering more abuses and being sold, his freedom was purchased

column13: Her father, John Farro, was a butcher born in Kentucky. Her mother, Jemima Jane, was born in Missouri. Unknown whether her parents were enslaved.
column15: Literate.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Raised in a middle class family in Chicago well before the Great Migration, Farro wrote True Love (copyright 1891), which at the time was thought to be the first novel by a black woman author

column10: Freeborn
column13: One of the twelve children of Sallie Prentice Harris and William Monteflora Harris, a West Indian immigrant
column15: Literate. Attended Quaker schools
column16: A member of the Congregational Church.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Caused controversy by enrolling in a previously all-white Quaker school; later became an abolitionist.

column10: Unknown. Possibly freed by the Civil War or 13th Amendment.
column13: Parents were Mary and Jesse Fearing, both enslaved.
column15: Literate. Gained basic literacy skills from friends, then in 1871 enrolled at Talladega College and studied until 9th grade.

column18: Spent 23 years in the Congo as a missionary.

column10: Freed by Union forces on 9 August 1961 when they occupied Roanoke Island. Legally freed by the Emancipation Proclamation on January 1, 1863
column13: One of ten children born to Abel Ferebee, a minister of the African Methodist Episcopal (AME) Zion Church, and Chloe. Both parents were enslaved

column15: Attended a Freedman's Bureau school. Later enrolled at the Hampton Institute in Virginia and was tutored by a white judge for a career in law
column16: A minister, apparently in the African Methodist Episcopal church
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Though unsuccessful when running for election in North Carolina (and even briefly jailed on charges of forging school vouchers, in spite of a lack of evidence), Ferebee remained interested in politics and active as a minister

column10: purchased for $200 by an abolitionist sympathizer. This debt was repaid with eleven months of Ferguson's work and $100 from a NY merchant.
column13: Parents names are unknown. Her mother was enslaved.
column15: Illiterate
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Also known as "Katy Ferguson." Taught Sunday school by reciting memorized passages of the Bible. Taught both white and black children who had no parents.
Free before 13th Amendment.

column13: The fourth child of Caleb Alexander and Mary Jane Driver Collins, free African Americans
column15: Literate. Earned a degree in social work from NYU
column16: Unclear. A member of an interfaith organization.
column18: Developed and worked in several settlement houses (especially in Baltimore), and combatted institutionalized forms of racism

column11: Unknown Status

column10: Freed by his second owner, Colonel Samuel Overton (further details unknown)
column13: His mother was enslaved
column15: Educational details are unknown.

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Bought the facility for First African Baptist Church (in Lexington, KY) and was preacher for the largest congregation in Kentucky; also remained in the city throughout a June 1833 cholera outbreak in order to bury the dead

column18: First African American woman to drive a coach for the postal service. Became a business owner at age 70. A frontierswoman who drank, smoke, and got in a shootout.

column10: Freed by the Civil War

column18: A member of the Republican party who was elected to the Atlanta city council in 1870 but voted out in 1872, Finch was also an AME minister until his expulsion from the church in 1885

column8: Unclear if she was ever enslaved.

column13: African American mother (status unknown) and a white father from France.

Free before 13th Amendment.

column10: Slavery was abolished in Utah in 1862.  Flake's former owner, who was living in California, subsequently asked Brigham Young to sell Flake. Young pretended not to have seen Flake and is thought to have freed him Flake had already been listed in the 1850 and 1860 census, which implies that was seen as free
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column16: Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints
column18: Possibly free before 13th Amendment. A devout Mormon who was the bodyguard of Joseph Smith and was allegedly freed by Brigham Young

column15: Presumably literate. A minister who attempted to create a secondary school

column10: Unknown. During the Civil War and Reconstruction he was educated in American Missionary Association schools
column13: His father was Festus, an enslaved shoemaker. His mother, Isabella Flipper, was enslaved in the household of a Methodist minister

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An AME leader who excelled at fundraising and building his parish  and who successfully tried to prevent a merger with the AME Zion church

column10: Freeborn
column13: Parents were Lydia and Francis Thorn
column15: Literate. A teacher and school founder
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Founded two schools in California at a time when African Americans were excluded from all public schools there

column10: Freeborn
column13: The fourth child of former slaves who lived at the time in Schenectady, New York
column15: Literate.

Published an autobiography called A Brand Plucked from the Fire https://archive.org/details/brandpluckedfrom00footrich/page/n5 (1879)

column10: Escaped in 1847 via the Underground Railroad, even disguising himself for some segments as a white woman

column10: Escaped from slavery in the 1860s. He traveled through Arkansas and southwestern Missouri, eventually making it to Iowa with help from the Underground Railroad
column13: His parents (names unknown) were living as free in Iowa but were kidnapped into slavery
column15: No evidence of literacy. Could speak multiple languages
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An escaped slave who fought in the Civil War and was honored for more than fifty years of employment at Rock Island (Illinois) Arsenal
Free before 13th Amendment. Minister and activist
Free before 13th Amendment. Portrait painter

column10: Made numerous escape attempts and finally escaped to Union-occupied Memphis on 26 June 1865. Reached Memphis with his family on Fourth of July 1865
column13: He was the son of a white man and an enslaved black woman, possibly John and Susan Hughes
column15: Literate. Attended night school in Chicago after the Civil War
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Escaped from slavery, later writing (possibly with assistance from another person) an autobiography
Free before 13th Amendment. Revolutionary war soldier
Free before 13th Amendment. Photographer

column10: Purchased his freedom in 1829, having saved enough money through his work as a blacksmith
column13: His parents' names are unknown. His mother appears to have been owned by a tavern keeper
column15: Literate. Learned to read and write from the daughter of his mistress
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Hunt gained fame and respect in Richmond for helping twelve people escape from a fire in 1811, and also used his skills as a carriage maker and blacksmith to support the Americans during the War of 1812

column10: Freeborn
column13: The third of four children of Mariah A. (Alexander) Gibbs, originally of Kentucky, and Mifflin Wistar Gibbs, originally of Pennsylvania
column15: Literate. Earned an MA from Oberlin.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. One of the first African American women to graduate from Oberlin, she advocated for human rights during her 27 years abroad with her husband (a U.S. consul) and after returning to the U.S.

column10: Apparently freed by Emancipation
column13: the son of enslaved artisan Osborne Hunter and Mary Hunter, also enslaved
column15: Literate
column18: An educator, civil servant in the post office, journalist, and political activist in North Carolina who had ties to the Democratic party

column13: his father Stanton Hunton was born enslaved and purchased his freedom as a bricklayer; his mother was a Free Black
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. YMCA leader and first African American executive of the YMCA

column10: Freeborn
column13: Her father, Sam B. Hyers, and her mother (Annie B. Hyers?) were musicians living in California
column15: Formal schooling is unknown. Extensively trained in music.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A soprano raised in California who toured nationwide with her sister Emma Louise Hyers

column10: Freeborn
column13: Her father, Sam B. Hyers, and her mother (Annie B. Hyers?) were musicians living in California
column15: Formal schooling is unknown. Extensively trained in music.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A singer raised in California who toured nationwide with her sister, Anna Madah Hyers

column10: Freeborn
column13: Her parents and maiden name are unknown
column15: Unknown
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. The second wife of Sam B. Hyers (father of the Hyers sisters), she was an accomplished contralto singer who was the first solo Black female recording artist

column10: Apparently freed by Emancipation
column13: Unknown
column15: Literate. Learned to read while still enslaved from the jeweler for whom he worked and the jeweler's wife
column18: A North Carolina state senator (1868–1874) and congressman for the Second District from his election in 1874 until 1876

column10: Freed by the Civil War (unclear exactly when during the war)
column13: Likely the son of his owner, Dr. William Ikard. His mother, who was named King, was an enslaved woman owned by William Ikard
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: A cattle driver on the Ikard-Goodnight Trail who was inducted to the Texas Trail of Fame in 1997

column11: Unknown status at birth, free before 1866
column18: Unknown  Status at Birth, later free/ Revolutionary War soldier

column11: Unknown status at birth, later free
column18: Revolutionary War soldier and sailor. Allegedly a waiter to George Washington

column10: Purchased his freedom by 1761 using money earned from his work as a shoemaker. He also acquired several acres of land
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A shoemaker and farmer who unsuccessfully tried to leave his property to a woman named Violet, who was denied access due to her enslaved status. His epitaph, written by Daniel Bliss, a Tory and Harvard-educated lawyer, became famous

column13: Unknown
column15: Unknown
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. First recorded African American to own property in Albany, NY

column10: Unknown. Her father purchased his freedom and then his wife's (date unknown). Apparently free by age 11, when taken to Ohio.
column11: Unknown status at birth, free before 1866
column13: Monroe and Mary Douglas Mitchell. Her father, who had been enslaved, hired his time and earned money as a carpenter, eventually purchasing his freedom and then his wife's. (years unknown)
column15: Literate. Three years of public school education. 1868 enrolled at Berea College
column16: Methodist. A member of the St. Paul AME Church.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Dismissed from a teaching job in KY on account of her race. Active club and organization member and president of the Ladies Orphans Home Society

column10: Unknown. Possibly freed by the Civil War or 13th Amendment.
column13: The seventh of thirteen children of the Reverend Anderson Jackson, who was enslaved, and his wife, Clara
column15: Literate. Learned to read and write while young. Attended a night school for African American children. In 1879 Jackson entered Fisk University in Nashville, Tennessee
column18: An educator who introduced an industrial education in Corsicana, Texas, following the example of Booker T. Washington

column10: He was captured in the Civil War while acting as a body servant for his legal owner, the farmer Charles G. Dickerson. Instead of being freed, he was returned to his legal owner. There is no indication that he was freed prior to the 13th Amendment.
column13: One of four children born to Hulda and James Jackson, who were both enslaved
column15: Literate. He was taught basic literacy skills by Sarah Ellen Wallace, whom he later married. He was also privately educated by white and black citizens.
column18: A businessman, and civic leader for whom Jackson Ward in Richmond, VA was named. Also organized of the 1907 "Negro Exhibit" about African American accomplishments and was the first African American attorney to practice before the Virginia Supreme Court

column10: Escaped in 1853 with a sister and her mother but were caught and sold. Escaped again in 1862 only to be caught by a slave trader pretending to be a Union officer. Escaped again in 1863
column13: Her parents, Ellen Turner and Westly Jackson, were enslaved with different masters
column15: Literate
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Escaped from slavery multiple times and wrote a narrative of her experiences to help finance her studies
Free before 13th Amendment. Professional boxer

column10: Freeborn
column13: Her mother was Jane Wisson (or Wilson) or Jane Cox; her father is unknown. Both parents were free
column15: Literate. Wrote that God instantaneously made her literate.
column16: Active in the Holiness Movement. Split from the AME church because of her belief in celibacy and joined the United Society of Believers in Christ's Second Appearing (the Shakers)
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Charismatic itinerant preacher. Wrote an autobiography called Gifts of Power about her religious experiences
First officially designated black chaplain in the US Army

column11: Unk. Born 1865, 18 days before  13th Amendment ratified
column18: Educator and athlete

column10: Escaped in 1835 and hid in a crawl space for seven years. Rejoined her children in 1842, who had been sent north (presumably by their white father, who had bought them). In 1852 Cornelia Grinnell Willis paid for the freedom of Jacobs and her children, who were living in the north and feared being recaptured due to the Fugitive Slave Act
column13: Her parents, Delilah and Elijah, were both enslaved.
column15: Literate. Learned to read while living with her mother's  owner.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Wrote under the pseudonym "Linda Brent". Antislavery activist and relief worker during the Civil War

column10: Escaped to Providence, Rhode Island while traveling through the north with his legal owner, the Congressman Samuel Tredwell Sawyer
column13: The son of Elijah, a carpenter and Delilah Horniblow, the daughter of a woman who had been freed but re-enslaved around the time of the American Revolution. John Jacobs was the brother of Harriet Ann Jacobs.
column15: Apparently literate. Left a note saying "no longer yours" before escaping from slavery
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. After escaping from slavery he became an autobiographer and abolitionist speaker who helped other enslaved people escape.

column10: Her father, Samuel Treadwell Sawyer, bought her freedom and sent her to the north. Although she was sent to Brooklyn as a "gift" to a member of her father's family, she appears to have gained her freedom eventually
column13: Her mother, Harriet Jacobs, was enslaved; her father was a white lawyer
column15: Literate. Learned to read from her mother and later continued in Boston schools.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Daughter of author Harriet Jacobs. A teacher, relief worker, and school founder

column10: Sometime after the marriage in 1812 between William Allen and Maria Malleville, who was a member of the family that owned Jacobs, Jacobs moved with the couple to Maine. Slavery was illegal in Maine, so Jacobs' status changed to that of a servant.
column13: Unknown
column15: Her educational background is unknown, but she apparently had a well-marked Bible
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Characterized as a deeply pious and perpetually cheerful woman by Mrs. T. C. Upham, who wrote Narrative of Phebe Ann Jacobs. http://www.oxfordaasc.com/article/ps/ps-aasc-0328?hi=17&highlight=1&from=quick&pos=1. This may have been inspiration for the character of Uncle Tom in Uncle Tom's Cabin

column10: Freed in 1811 by Zephaniah Kingsley, her owner and the father of her three children.
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Born Anta Majigeen Ndiaye in Senegal. Spent several years in Haiti because of the changing racial climate in Florida during the decades after the transition from Spanish to American control

column10: Ran away within a year of being enslaved on Kent Island, though he was recaptured. After being returned to his owner, he wrote a letter in Arabic to his father. James Oglethorpe, a philanthropist, learned of this and helped arrange for Jallo's freedom. Jallo sailed for England in 1773; his freedom was legally purchased the following year
column15: Literate He underwent koranic and Arabic studies
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Captured into slavery while traveling near the Gambia River, Jallo survived the Middle Passage and slavery and in later years was charged with promoting English trade in Senegambia

column10: Freeborn
column13: Parents were former slaves living in Connecticut
column15: No evidence of literacy
column16: Joined the Presbyterian [Congregationalist] Church at age 14 and later the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Became a domestic servant to Joseph Smith Jr. after converting to Mormonism. Later migrated to Salt Lake City and sought equal inclusion of African Americans into the church

column8: Status changed during the Civil War
column10: Likely enslaved before the Civil War, Miles enlisted in mid-1863 in the Union Army. His status during the war is not explicitly stated
column13: Unknown
column14: No evidence of runaway. However, it is not clear under what circumstances he enlisted in the Union army
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Freed by Civil war military service. Earned the Medal of Honor, the Butler Medal and a promotion to the rank of sergeant for his bravery in the Battle of New Market Heights, during which he lost an arm

column10: Self-liberation
column13: Father unknown; James was separated from his mother and siblings at age 8 when they were sold
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Was a minister and abolitionist in New Bedford and Boston, MA, and Syracuse, and Rochester. NY

column8: Status changed during the Civil War
column10: When Richmond fell in 1865 he was able to join other freedmen
column13: His father, Philip Jasper, was an enslaved preacher. His mother, Nina, was also enslaved and was head servant of the Peachy family
column15: Literate. Learned to read from a fellow enslaved person
column18: A Baptist preacher in Richmond, VA who was well known for his oratory and for a geocentric “The Sun Do Move” sermon

column10: Emancipated after his literacy became known. Apparently local magistrates were afraid that he would teach others how to read

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. The author of a significant autobiography, Jea toured, preached, and held revivals in the U.S., while at sea, during multiple European tours, and in the West Indies.

column10: He was apparently living as a freedman by the time he was in his seventies
column13: His parents were George, a foreman and overseer, and Ursula, a pastry cook and laundress. Both parents were enslaved at Monticello in Virginia
column14: His memoirs make no reference to escape attempts, though it is possible that he is the "Isaac" whom Thomas Jefferson's son-in-law Thomas Mann Randolph wrote tried to escape in 1812
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Possibly Free before 13th Amendment. A blacksmith whose Memoirs of a Monticello Slave were recorded by Charles Campbell but published only in 1951

column11: Unknown status at birth, free before 1866
column13: Father was William Jenkins. It is not known whether his father was a white slaveholder or a free black, and his mother's name is unknown. Jenkins received a sound education at the hands of a private tutor hired by his father. In 1837 he took up residence in Columbus, Ohio,
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Editor and abolitionist

column10: He was likely enslaved until he was a young man. There is no indication of when he was freed
column11: Likely enslaved
column13: Unknown. He was possibly of mixed ancestry; the 1880 Federal Census describes an Edmund Jenkins as "mulatto"
column15: Illiterate
column18: A law enforcement officer for several decades in Mount Pleasant, South Carolina

column10: Purchased for $120 and almost immediately manumitted by Massachusetts Senator Daniel Webster
column13: The son of Benjamin (or William) Jennings, a white English trader, and an enslaved African American (name unknown) who was owned by President and First Lady Madison
column15: Literate. Dictated his memoir

Free born first Black patent holder and abolitionist

column10: Freeborn
column13: Her parents were Elizabeth (maiden name unknown) and Thomas L. Jennings. Her father was a tailor, inventor and abolitionist
column15: Literate. Worked as a teacher
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. After she was attacked because of her race when attempting to take public transportation in New York City, the court affirmed her right to ride transit but awarded only $225 in damages

column10: Secured his freedom by some means in the 1750s or 1760s
column13: His parents were enslaved (names unknown)
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A fisherman, volunteer firefighter, and wealthy free black in South Carolina, Jeremiah was executed in 1865 after being accused of attempting to foment a slave rebellion

column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Enslaved in Texas, Moses was a preacher and a farmer

column10: Freeborn
column13: Her parents (names unknown) were from Maryland but lived in Montreal at the time of Amelia's birth

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Launched a monthly religious periodical, The Joy, for a Black Youth audiecec and wrote three novels that dealt with poverty, alcohol, and domestic violence (but not directly with race)

column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Lived in a large community of southern free blacks. Peddled wares, worked as a realtor, became a slaveowner

column11: Unknown status at birth, Alabama, 1865.
column13: nothing known

column13: Unknown.
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Likely born in Africa, Johnson was enslaved in colonial Virginia and later became a freedman, planter, and slaveowner

column11: Unknown status at birth, free before 1866.
column18: Unknown  Status at Birth, free Before 13th Amendment

column11: Unknown status at birth, free before 1866.

column18: Unknown  Status at Birth, free Before 13th Amendment

column10: Freeborn
column13: One of nine children born to Benjamin Tucker Tanner, a leader in the AME church, and Sarah Elizabeth Miller
column15: Literate. Earned a MD from Woman's Medical College of Pennsylvania, graduating with high honors in 1891
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. The first woman to pass the medical examination in Alabama, she was a resident physician at Tuskegee Institute and founded a nurse's training program

column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy

column13: Parents were John and Jane Williams
column15: Unknown. She arranged for her children to be educated.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. She may have been the escaped woman, also named Jane, referenced in Hannah Crafts' The Bondwoman's Narrative. Courageously testified in court in 1855 that she had escaped of her own will.
Free before 13th Amendment.

column11: Unknown Status at Birth, free before 1866
column18: Unknown  Status at Birth, free Before 13th Amendment

column13: Unknown
column15: Apparently literate. He signed his name on one of his paintings.

column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Considered to be the last fugitive slave returned to the South from the North under the Fugitive Slave Act of 1850. Emancipated during the Civil War.

It is possible that Johnson subsequently had to repay McIntire before truly becoming free, likely sometime before 1808
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Escaped from slavery and worked on a ferry-boat on the Ohio River, becoming a respected citizen. His story is largely known through oral tradition.

column10: Unknown. Accounts differ, but by one account he purchased his own freedom.
column13: Unknown
column15: Literate. Frederick Douglass described Johnson as a book owner and newspaper reader.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A prominent citizen in New Bedford, MA, who helped many individuals (including Frederick Douglass) escape from slavery, and who also joined the California gold rush
Free before 13th Amendment.

column10: Freed after the fall of the Confederacy
column13: His parents were of unknown names. His mother and her siblings were apparently born to an African parent and separated from each other by slavery.

column18: A Baptist preacher and author who was a missionary in Cameroon, and worked and raised money for missionary purposes in both the U.S. and Great Britain
column19: Great image at https://docsouth.unc.edu/neh/johnsontl/menu.html and different at https://docsouth.unc.edu/neh/johnson1/menu.html

column18: Free before 13th Amendment.
Free before 13th Amendment.

column10: Manumitted in 1820 when his father, who was his legal owner, asked the Mississippi legislature to free William

column15: Literate
column16: Attended church but did not maintain a continuous affiliation with any particular denomination
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. As a freedman, Johnson was one of the leading citizens of Natchez, Mississippi who wrote a 14-volume diary

column13: His parents were enslaved
column15: Literate. As a child he saved up to purchase a primer and then asked people to teach him to read. He later attended a Quaker-operated night school
column16: Methodist, then--in response to the racism of white Methodist parishioners-- Episcopal
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. The first black person to become an Episcopal priest, Jones was also an organizer of the Free Africa Society (in Philadelphia), an abolitionist, and ultimately an opponent of the American Colonization Society

column11: Born 3 days after 13th Amendment ratified.
column13: the son of Clifford Milner and Mary Jones Milner.

column18: Free before 13th Amendment.

column10: Unknown. Possibly freed by the Civil War or 13th Amendment.
column13: His parents, Barney and Cherry, were enslaved in the High family
column14: No evidence of runaway, though Jones was jailed by one owner for his resistance to slavery
column15: Apparently literate. It seems that his autobiography was largely self-published

It was in Tennessee that he received training as a tailor.

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A sexton at First Baptist Church who helped over 800 individuals who were escaping on the Underground Railroad and who, during the Civil War, buried and kept records of 3,000 men who died at the Elmira prison camp for Confederate soldiers

column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy

column11: Unknown Status at birth, KY 1860.
column13: Names and status unknown
column15: Literate. Graduated from Fisk University in 1886
column16: Baptist, but applied to join a Congregationalist mission group
column18: Spent years in Mozambique as a missionary until tensions with white missionaries caused her to request reassignment and ultimately to return

column11: Unknown Status at birth, AL 1860.
column13: the only son of Alice Royal, a mixed-race woman, and an unidentified white father.

column18: Free before 13th Amendment.

column13: Unknown

column15: Literate. He likely never attended school formally.

column10: Freeborn
column13: parents: Charles Woodby and Elizabeth B. Frazier.

column16: Unknown. A contributor to religious magazines and journals.

column15: Literate.

column15: No evidence of literacy

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. McPherson was a millenarian Christian who viewed himself as divine and waged a series of unsuccessful lawsuits

column13: The names of his father, a Baptist preacher, and his mother are unknown

column10: Fled from enslavement in South Carolina and participated in the 1715-1717 Yamasee War. He was sold back into slavery but in 1738 he successfully petitioned the new governor of Florida, Manuel de Montiano, for the freedom for all slaves who or would flee from Carolina. Re-enslaved in 1741 after being identified by the English, by 1759 he was again a fort commander in Florida
column13: Unknown. Menendez was of Mandingo origin
column15: Literate
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Escaped from slavery and became a military leader north of St. Augustine, FL, which functioned as the first officially sanctioned free African American community in the US

column15: Apparently literate. One of his businesses started a newspaper

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Known in his old age as Grandpère Augustin, Metoyer was a Louisiana freedman who accumulated a large estate, legally owned 25 slaves by 1820, and purchased many of his family members in order to emancipate them

column13: The son of Marie-Thérèse Coincoin, a former slave who was a successful agriculturalist, and Claude Thomas Pierre Metoyer, a wealthy French merchant and planter. Coincoin and Metoyer were in a nineteen-year relationship
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Like his brother Augustin, Louis Metoyer was a prominent and slave-owning Creole in Louisiana.

column10: He likely escaped slavery during the Civil War as a "contraband"
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Received the Medal of Honor for service in the Navy during the Civil War

column13: One of thirteen children born to Datus and Lois Freeman, both of whom died from tuberculosis

column18: Unknown  Status at Birth, free Before 13th Amendment

Napier was possibly the first African American Treasury Department clerk, held various patronage appointments in Nashville, served as city councilman, and in 1911 was register of the U.S. Treasury. column10: Freeborn
column13: The oldest of five daughters born to William Rollin, a businessman whose family migrated from Saint Domingue (now Haiti) in 1792, and Margarette, a woman whose family was also from the Caribbean
column15: Literate. Educated by a French family and at a Catholic parish school for free people and then at the Quaker Institute for Colored Youth (now Cheyney University) in Philadelphia
column16: Raised Catholic but joined the Episcopal Church
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. From a prominent family in South Carolina, she won one of the earliest civil rights cases in the country, published the first biography of a freeborn black man, and worked as a copyist to support her family

column10: Freeborn
column13: The third daughter of William Rollin, wood factor, and Margarette, housekeeper. The family is listed as "mulatto" on the census
column15: Literate. Educated through tutoring, private schools in Charleston, and secondary schools in Boston and Philadelphia
column16: Unlisted. Worked with Bishop James Lynch, an African Methodist Episcopal Church missionary, to found a school.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. One of the Rollins sisters, she attempted to raise money to sustain the Rollins Family School, may have been engaged to marry a white South Carolina senator, and died at the age of 25.

column10: Freeborn
column13: She was one of the five daughters of Margarette Rollin and William Rollin, a free man of color
column15: Literate. Thought to have attended school in Philadelphia.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. One of the Rollin sisters that operated a prominent salon in Charleston, Louisa joined the American Woman Suffrage Association and also spoke in 1869 before the South Carolina House of Representatives

column10: Starting from age 14 he made repeated attempts to run away. After being sold to a planter in Florida, Roper was able to convince a ship captain to take him on as a steward. He escaped to New York.

column15: Literate. Attended boarding school and briefly the University College in London
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. He escaped to the north via the "maritime Underground Railroad" and then traveled to England in 1835, where he became a lecturer and author.

column10: Unknown
column11: Possibly born enslaved
column13: Unknown. He was likely of mixed African American, Native American, and white ancestry.
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A frontiersman who lived among the Crow and accompanied numerous expeditions to the West

column10: Freeborn
column13: The youngest of four children born to Jam, a laborer, and Mary Ross. Her father was born in Africa, according to the census
column15: Literate. She was denied admittance to a Nantcuket high school on account of her race. In spite ofthis discrimination, she was apparently well educated and proficient in French.

column18: A businessman and Republican party member who held several appointed posts in Georgia and was active in the NAACP and Niagara Movement

column10: Freeborn
column13: Unknown
column15: Literate. A journalist and newspaper editor.

However, the new husband of Scott's owner, Massachusetts abolitionist Dr. Calvin Clifford Chaffee, was embarrassed to become Scott's owner and arranged for Scott and his wife to be freed
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: A litigant in the famous Dred Scott v. John F. A. Sanford case, which was highly polarizing in the lead-up to the Civil War.

column14: Tried to escape slavery through legal means.
column15: Unknown
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Married Dred Scott in 1836 or 1837, and in 1846 they each filed lawsuits demanding their freedom

column10: Unknown

column13: His parents were enslaved; their names are unknown

column15: Basic literacy. Enrolled in school at age twenty-five

column8: Status changed during the Civil War

column13: Unknown
column14: No evidence of runaway, though it is unclear under what circumstances he enlisted in the Union Army
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Walley served in the military for 29 years and was one of twenty-three African American soldiers to earn the Medal of Honor during the so-called Indian Wars

column10: Little is known about his early life. He was kidnapped in 1861 by Confederates and forced to work as a servant, then liberated by Union troops and sent to Pennsylvania in 1862
column13: His parents' names are unknown. Walls issued contradictory statements on his parents status as enslaved or free
column15: Literate. One year of formal education in Pennsylvania
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A Union army veteran, farmer, Florida attorney, newspaper owner, twice elected to the U.S. House of Representatives but only seated for one year due to contested results. Subsequently served as a state senator

column10: Born in Kentucky shortly before the start of the Civil War. Unclear exactly when he gained his freedom (possibly at Emancipation)
column13: His parents, Henry Walters and Harriet Mathers, were both enslaved
column15: Literate. Studied in private schools from 1866 to 1871 in Bardstown
