column15: Presumably literate. One condition of his emancipation was that he would be taught to read.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A marble cutter and sculptor who spent his later years in Europe

column10: In 1820 he and his parents escaped to Greenwich, New Jersey
column13: His parents were William Ward and Anne (maiden name unknown), both enslaved
column15: Literate. Attended the African Free School in New York City
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A teacher, preacher of several congregations (one of which was all-white), and a traveling lecturer for the American Anti-Slavery Society, and newspaper editor

column10: He became free during the Civil War
column13: Unknown
column14: Unknown. It is unclear how he gained his freedom during the Civil War
column15: There is no mention of formal education, but Ward briefly served in the Louisiana legislature
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. A military veteran who was involved in the lead-up to the 1873 Colfax Massacre (an event in which African Americans seeking mutual protection engaged in a battle with their attackers but were massacred in large numbers, including after surrender). Briefly served in the Louisiana legislature

column8: Status changed during the Civil War
column10: Enlisted in the 118th United States Colored Infantry (USCI) Company H, 19 September 1864

column18: Free before 13th Amendment

column15: No evidence of runaway

column10: He was liberated by Union troops late in the Civil War

column18: The leading African American figure of the late 19th and early 20th Century. Author of Up from Slavery and founder of Tuskegee Institute. Urged southern black people to accommodate to social segrgation and concentrate on economic self-advancement, a position that came to be challenged by W.E.B. Du Bois.

column11: Unknown Status at birth, WV 1858
column13: Daughter of Samuel Smith and Celia.
column15: Literate. One of the best students of Booker T. Washington, she later graduated from Hampton Institute in 1882

column13: Unknown
column15: Details of his education are unlisted. He apparently contributed a statement to the "Book of Negroes"

column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. In 1841 he led nineteen enslaved persons in a mutiny that successfully redirected the Creole, a slave trading ship, to the Bahamas. The British allowed the enslaved persons aboard to be free, but paid $110,330 to the U.S. as compensation for loss of property

column11: Unknown Status at Birth MS. C. 1861
column13: Her mother, Lucy Murray, worked as a washerwoman and may have been enslaved, and her father, James Murray, was an Irish immigrant

column18: An educator and club organizer who served as president of the National Association of Colored Women (NACW) and the International Council of Women of the Darker Races (ICWDR), she was also the third wife of Booker T. Washington

column10: In 1865 an uncle who had been liberated earlier in the war sent for Anna's parents, and the family moved to Williamstown

column15: Literate. Received an education in Williamstown, MA shortly after the Civil War
column16: Christian(?). Provided a religious education to children attending her orphanage.

Free before 13th Amendment

column10: Born free but bound as a servant until age 18 due to her mother's indentured contract. Freed from servitude in 1703, she later agreed to re-enter indentured servitude in order to marry an enslaved man. She initiated a series of lawsuits to secure the freedom of her children.
column13: The daughter of an indentured mother, Ann Williams, and an enslaved father, Daniel Webb
column14: No evidence of runaway. Resisted through legal channels the wrongful prolongation of her children's terms as indentured servants.
column15: No evidence of literacy.
column18: A litigant in Virginia who was able to ensure that her children eventually gained legal freedom

column10: Freeborn
column13: Webb's husband described her as the daughter of a wealthy Spaniard and “a woman of full African blood” who escaped from slavery while pregnant. She may instead have been the daughter of a Cuban official or the Spanish general and statesman Baldomero Espartero

column18: Free before 13th Amendment. An internationally renowned elocutionist who often performed The Christian Slave, a work that Harriet Beecher Stowe had developed specifically for Webb to perform, and who also performed Hiawatha while dressed as a Native American

column13: Unknown
column15: Literate. Began learning to read at age 31.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. After being emancipated and joining the Brethren religious movement, Weir left Virginia so as to avoid re-enslavement and became a preacher in Ohio.

column13: The eldest of the eight children of Jim Wells and Lizzie Warrenton, both of whom were enslaved
column15: Literate. Became a teacher at age 16
column16: Attended the African Methodist Episcopal Church's general conference
column18: A journalist, editor, and club organizer who was an anti-lynching activist, suffragist, and critic of activists who took too conservative of an approach

column10: Freeborn, though indentured and later captured by the Mexican army.
column13: Unknown
column15: No evidence of literacy.
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Known as the "Yellow Rose of Texas," West was an indentured servant in Texas. Historians have cast doubt on a contemporary's claim that West detained Santa Anna and thereby helped Sam Houston to victory.

column10: Freed in 1773 by the Wheatleys
column13: Unknown. Likely lived near the Gambia River, where Wheatley is thought to have been born
column15: Literate. Educated by the family of John Wheatley who bought her and wanted her to be able to read the Bible
column16: Christian. A convert to evangelical Calvinism. She was also familiar with animistic ancestor worship, solar worship, and Islam
column18: Free before 13th Amendment. Brought to  Boston in 1761 aboard a ship called the Phillis, she became a published poet at age 14 and traveled to England to continue her publications. She supported the Americans during the Revolutionary War

column16: Unknown. His wife was involved in the North Church, located in Portsmouth, NH
